author: Terry Frei
title: Frei: Patrick Roy is right: Dump the morning skate
text:
LOS ANGELES —The Avalanche isn't scheduled to travel to the Staples Center on Sunday for a morning skate in advance of its game against the Los Angeles Kings that night.
That's in keeping with Colorado's routine so far this season, when coach Patrick Roy has had the team come to the Pepsi Center on the morning of home games only for video work, meetings and voluntary aerobic work. The healthy scratches might skate, but that's it.
And now on this two-game Southern California road trip, which began at Anaheim on Friday night, the Avs are doing the morning work at the team hotels and going to the arenas only once, not until late afternoon.
I long have felt that morning skates are outdated, unnecessary and even counterproductive.
But in a sports world that tends to unquestionably buy in to the theory that if "B" follows "A," then "A" caused "B," and coaches often react defensively to avoid second-guessing, Roy probably will feel pressure to go back to conventional morning skates if the Avs struggle through the first 15 games or so.
Even if that's the way the things play out, I again would offer up the phrase from the study of statistics (no, not analytics): "Correlation does not imply causation."
Roy should stick to his plan, variations of which have been tried throughout recent years in the NHL — but haven't caught on. The Avalanche coach decided to do this as a continuation of his relentlessly touted "partnership" with the players, and in consultation with captain Gabe Landeskog, among others.
